sen.j: 清華家（せいがけ）とは、公家・公卿の家格のひとつで、大臣家の上で摂家に次ぐ家格。
sen.e: Seiga Family is one of the Kakaku (family status) of court noble or noble, which is the Kakaku above Daijinke (Daijin Family) and next to Sekke (Setsu Family).
The Seiga Family was one of the kakaku (family status) of court nobles or nobility, which is the kakaku above the daijinke (Daijin Family) and was next to the sekke (Setsu Family).
The Seiga Family was one of the kakaku (family status) of court nobles or nobility, which is the kakaku above the daijinke (Daijin Family) and was next to the sekke (Setsu Family).

sen.j: 近衛大将・大臣を兼任し、最高は太政大臣まで昇進できる家（ただし、江戸時代には太政大臣の就任要件として摂政・関白経験者に限られたために、清華家は左大臣が事実上の極官となる）。
sen.e: The family that can concurrently serve Konoe Taisho general and can be promoted up to grand minister of state (However, since the requirement for taking the position of grand minister of state in the Edo era was the person who once experienced regent or chief advisor to the Emperor, the highest official rank the Seiga family could virtually get was minister of the left).

The family concurrently served Konoe Taisho general and was thus promoted to grand minister of state (however, since the requirement for taking the position of grand minister of state in the Edo period was the person who had served as regent or chief advisor to the Emperor, the highest official rank the Seiga family could attain was that of minister of the left).

The family concurrently served Konoe Taisho general and was thus promoted to grand minister of state (however, since the requirement for taking the position of grand minister of state in the Edo period was the person who had served as regent or chief advisor to the Emperor, the highest official rank the Seiga family could attain was that of minister of the left).

sen.j: 英雄家ともいう。
sen.e: Also called Eiyu Family.
It was also called the Eiyu Family.
It was also called the Eiyu Family.

sen.j: 摂家とこの清華家の子弟は、公達（きんだち）と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Children of Sekke and Seiga Family were called Kindachi.
The children of Sekke and Seiga Family were called Kindachi.
The children of Sekke and Seiga Family were called Kindachi.

sen.j: 明治時代以前は、華族というと、この家柄のことを指していた。
sen.e: Before the Meiji era, new nobility meant this family.
Before the Meiji era, "new nobility" meant this family.
Before the Meiji period, new nobility meant this family.

sen.j: 明治の華族令によって、原則的には侯爵に叙されることになったが、維新の功績によって三条家は公爵とされ、また一旦侯爵とされた西園寺家と徳大寺家も後に公爵に陞爵した。
sen.e: According to Nobility's Act in the Meiji era, Seiga Family was, in principle, entitled to marquess, but, thanks to the achievements during the Meiji Restoration, Sanjo Family was entitled to duke, and Saionji Family and Tokudaiji Family that were once entitled to marquess were later entitled to duke by means of shosyaku (getting higher rank for the achievements).

According to the Nobility Act implemented in the Meiji era, the Seiga Family was, in principle, entitled to the title of marquess; however, thanks to the achievements during the Meiji Restoration, the Sanjo Family was entitled to the title of duke, while the Saionji and Tokudaiji families, which were formerly entitled to the title of marquess, were later entitled to the title of duke by means of shosyaku (attaining higher rank based on achievement).

According to the Nobility Act implemented in the Meiji period, the Seiga Family was, in principle, entitled to the title of marquess; however, thanks to the achievements during the Meiji Restoration, the Sanjo Family was entitled to the title of duke, while the Saionji and Tokudaiji families, which were formerly entitled to the title of marquess, were later entitled to the title of duke by means of shosyaku (attaining higher rank based on achievement).

sen.j: 清華家は最終的に以下の9家。
sen.e: Seiga Family is the following nine families in the end.
Ultimately, the Seiga Family comprised the following nine families:
Ultimately, the Seiga Family comprised the following nine families:

sen.j: なお、藤原北家閑院流の洞院家も、鎌倉～室町期に上記清華家と同等に太政大臣をたびたび輩出しているが、戦国時代の初めに断絶しているため、江戸時代に確立した清華家等の公家の家格に該当するものがない。
sen.e: Although Toin Family of Fujiwara Hokke-Kanin group also produced grand ministers of state from the Kamakura era through the Muromachi era as frequently as Seiga Family did, since the family line of Toin Family failed in the early Sengoku Period, Toin Family does not have Kakaku corresponding to that of court noble such as Seiga Family or other families established in the Edo era.

Although the Toin Family of the Fujiwara Hokke-Kanin group also produced grand ministers of state from the Kamakura era through the Muromachi era as frequently as the Seiga Family did, since the family line of the Toin Family failed in the early Sengoku period the Toin Family did not have kakaku corresponding to that of court noble, such as the Seiga Family or other families established during the Edo period.

Although the Toin Family of the Fujiwara Hokke-Kanin group also produced grand ministers of state from the Kamakura era through the Muromachi era as frequently as the Seiga Family did, since the family line of the Toin Family failed in the early Sengoku period the Toin Family did not have kakaku corresponding to that of court noble, such as the Seiga Family or other families established during the Edo period.

sen.j: 七家
sen.e: Seven families
Seven families
Seven families

sen.j: 久我家
sen.e: Koga Family
The Koga Family
The Koga Family

sen.j: 村上天皇の第八皇子具平親王の男右大臣源師房（1008年 - 1077年）を祖とする村上源氏の嫡流。
sen.e: The main branch of the family of Murakami-Genji (Murakami Gen clan), the originator of which is minister of the right MINAMOTO no Morofusa (1008 to 1077) who is son of Tomohira Imperial Prince who is the eighth prince of Murakami Emperor.

The main branch of the family of Murakami-Genji (Murakami Gen clan), the originator of which was minister of the right MINAMOTO no Morofusa (1008 to 1077), who was the son of Imperial Prince Tomohira, the eighth prince of Emperor Murakami.

The main branch of the family of Murakami-Genji (Murakami Gen clan), the originator of which was minister of the right MINAMOTO no Morofusa (1008 to 1077), who was the son of Imperial Prince Tomohira, the eighth prince of Emperor Murakami.

sen.j: 師房は御堂関白藤原道長の女婿（師房の妻は道長の娘尊子）、またその嫡男藤原頼通の養子となり、その子孫も摂関家と深い姻戚関係を築いた。
sen.e: Morofusa is Mido Kampaku (Michinaga FUJIWARA) FUJIWARA no Michinaga's daughter's husband (Morofusa's wife is Michinaga's daughter Takako), and became an adopted child of FUJIWARA no Yorimichi who is the heir of Michinaga, and the descendant of Morofusa also built a deep marital relationship with Sekkan Family (Sekkanke).

Morofusa was Mido Kampaku (Michinaga FUJIWARA) FUJIWARA no Michinaga's daughter's husband (Morofusa's wife was Michinaga's daughter Takako), and became an adopted child of FUJIWARA no Yorimichi, the heir of Michinaga; the descendant of Morofusa also built a deep marital relationship with the Sekkan Family (Sekkanke).

Morofusa was Mido Kampaku FUJIWARA no Michinaga's daughter's husband (Morofusa's wife was Michinaga's daughter Takako), and became an adopted child of FUJIWARA no Yorimichi, the heir of Michinaga; additionally, the descendant of Morofusa built a deep relationship through intermarriage with the Sekkan Family (Sekkanke).

sen.j: 師房の五世孫内大臣源通親（1149年 - 1202年）は高階栄子と組んで時の関白九条兼実を追い落とし、「源博陸」とあだ名されるほどの権勢家であった。
sen.e: Naidaijin (minister) MINAMOTO no Michichika (1149 to 1202), who was Morofusa's fifth generation grandson, expelled then chief advisor to the Emperor Kanezane KUJO in conspiracy with TAKASHINA no Eishi, and was a person who flaunted his power to be nicknamed "Gen Haku Riku."

Naidaijin (minister) MINAMOTO no Michichika (1149 to 1202), who was Morofusa's fifth-generation grandson, expelled the chief advisor to the Emperor Kanezane KUJO in a conspiracy with TAKASHINA no Eishi, and was a person who flaunted his power to be nicknamed "Gen Haku Riku."

Naidaijin (minister) MINAMOTO no Michichika (1149 to 1202), who was Morofusa's fifth-generation grandson, expelled the chief advisor to the Emperor Kanezane KUJO in a conspiracy with TAKASHINA no Eishi, and was a person who flaunted his power, thereby earning the nickname 'Gen Haku Riku.'

sen.j: 久我家嫡流は長く源氏長者や淳和院・奨学院両院別当を兼任したが、室町時代、武家源氏の将軍足利義満にその地位を奪われた。
sen.e: The main branch of the family of Koga Family had long served concurrently leader of Genji, and chief of both Junnain Palace and Shogakuin college, but the position was deprived of by Shogun Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA of Samurai-Genji (Gen clan as samurai families) in the Muromachi era.

The main branch of the Koga Family had long served concurrently as the leader of Genji and chief of both the Junnain Palace and Shogakuin College, but such a position was removed by Shogun Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA of Samurai-Genji (the Gen clan as samurai families) during the Muromachi period.

The main branch of the Koga Family had long served concurrently as the leader of Genji and chief of both the Junnain Palace and Shogakuin College, but such a position was removed by Shogun Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA of Samurai-Genji (the Gen clan as samurai families) during the Muromachi period.

sen.j: 「久我家」の名称は、京都西南、山城国愛宕郡久我の地に別業「久我水閣」があったことが由来。
sen.e: The name of "Koga Family" comes from the fact that there was a villa "Koga Water Castle" in Koga, Otagi-gun Yamashiro-no-kuni, in the southwest of Kyoto.
The Koga family name comes from the fact that there was a villa "Koga Water Castle" in Koga, Otagi-gun Yamashiro-no-kuni, in the southwest of Kyoto.
The Koga family name comes from the fact that there was a villa 'Koga Water Castle' in Koga, Otagi-gun Yamashiro-no-kuni, in the southwest of Kyoto.

sen.j: 分家の公家諸家としては、大臣家の中院家、および羽林家の六条家・岩倉家・千種家・東久世家・久世家・梅渓家・愛宕家・植松家の九家がある。
sen.e: The branch court noble families are nine families, that are Nakanoin Family of Daijinke, Rokujo Family, Iwakura Family, Chikusa Faimily, Higashikuze Family, Kuze Family, Umetani Family, Otagi Family, Uematsu Family of Urin Family.

There were nine branch court noble families: the Nakanoin Family of Daijinke, the Rokujo, the Iwakura, the Chikusa, the Higashikuze, the Kuze, the Umetani, the Otagi, and the Uematsu (of the Urin Family).

There were nine branch court noble families: the Nakanoin Family of Daijinke, the Rokujo, the Iwakura, the Chikusa, the Higashikuze, the Kuze, the Umetani, the Otagi, and the Uematsu of the Urin Family.
sen.cmt: スペース削除原文にない()削除

sen.j: 家業：笛、江戸時代の家禄：700石、家紋：五つ竜胆車。
sen.e: Family business: flute, Karoku (hereditary stipend) in the Edo era: seven hundred koku, Crest: Itsutsu Rindoguruma crest (five gentians annulet).
Family business: flute; karoku (hereditary stipend) in the Edo period: seven hundred koku; crest: the Itsutsu Rindoguruma (five gentians annulet)
Family business: flute; karoku (hereditary stipend) in the Edo period: seven hundred koku; crest: the Itsutsu Rindoguruma (five gentians annulet)

sen.j: 三条家（転法輪三条家）
sen.e: Sanjo Family (Temporin-Sanjo Family)
The Sanjo Family (Temporin-Sanjo Family)
The Sanjo Family (Temporin-Sanjo Family)

sen.j: 藤原北家閑院流（太政大臣藤原公季の子孫）。
sen.e: Fujiwara Hokke-Kanin group (descendant of grand minister of state FUJIWARA no Kinsuke).
The Fujiwara Hokke-Kanin group (descended from Grand Minister of State FUJIWARA no Kinsuke)
The Fujiwara Hokke-Kanin group (descended from Grand Minister of State FUJIWARA no Kinsuke)

sen.j: 大納言藤原公実の長男太政大臣三条実行（1080年 - 1162年）が初代。
sen.e: The first generation is grand minister of state Saneyuki SANJO (1080 to 1162) who is the eldest son of chief councillor of state FUJIWARA no Kimizane.
The first generation was Grand Minister of State Saneyuki SANJO (1080 to 1162), who was the eldest son of Chief Councilor of State FUJIWARA no Kimizane.
The first generation was Grand Minister of State Saneyuki SANJO (1080 to 1162), who was the eldest son of Chief Councilor of State FUJIWARA no Kimizane.

sen.j: この家から分かれた大臣家の正親町三条家（嵯峨実愛の時に「嵯峨」と改称）と区別するために転法輪を冠して呼ぶことが多い。
sen.e: To distinguish over Ogimachi-Sanjo Family (renamed as "Saga" at the time of Sanenaru SAGA) of Daijinke, which was descendented from Sanjo Family, Sanjo Family is called with the prefix Temporin added most of the time.

To further distinguish the Ogimachi-Sanjo Family (renamed "Saga" at the time of Sanenaru SAGA) of Daijinke, which was descended from the Sanjo Family, the Sanjo Family is most often referred to with the prefix Temporin.

To further distinguish the Ogimachi-Sanjo Family (renamed 'Saga' at the time of Sanenaru SAGA) of Daijinke, which was descended from the Sanjo Family, the Sanjo Family is most often referred to with the prefix Temporin.

sen.j: 庶流は大臣家の正親町三条家・三条西家を始め、羽林家の滋野井家・姉小路家等多数。
sen.e: Branch families are many including from Ogimachi-Sanjo Family and Sanjonishi Family of Daijinke to Shigenoi Family and Anegakoji Family of Urin Family.
The numerous branch families included the Ogimachi-Sanjo Family and Sanjonishi Family of Daijinke, as well as the Shigenoi Family and Anegakoji Family (of the Urin Family).
The numerous branch families included the Ogimachi-Sanjo Family and Sanjonishi Family of Daijinke, as well as the Shigenoi Family and Anegakoji Family of the Urin Family.

sen.j: 家業：笛・装束。
sen.e: Family business: flute and Shozoku (costume).
Family business: flute and shozoku (costume)
Family business: flute and shozoku (costume)

sen.j: 江戸時代の家禄：469石、家紋：唐菱花。
sen.e: Karoku (hereditary stipend) in the Edo era: 469 koku, Crest: Karabishibana crest (Chinese rhombic flower).
Karoku (hereditary stipend) during the Edo period: 469 koku; crest: the Karabishibana crest (Chinese rhombic flower)

sen.j: 西園寺家
sen.e: Saionji Family
The Saionji Family
The Saionji Family

sen.j: 藤原北家閑院流。
sen.e: Fujiwara Hokke-Kanin group
The Fujiwara Hokke-Kanin group
The Fujiwara Hokke-Kanin group

sen.j: 同じく公実の次男中納言西園寺通季（1090年 - 1128年）を祖とする。
sen.e: The originator is vice councilor of state Michisue SAIONJI (1090 to 1128) who is the second son of Kimizane.
The originator was Vice Councilor of State Michisue SAIONJI (1090 to 1128), the second son of Kimizane.
The originator was Chunagon (vice-councilor of state) Michisue SAIONJI (1090 to 1128), the second son of Kimizane.
sen.cmt: "Vice Councilor of State" -> "Chunagon (vice-councilor of state)" に変更しました。

sen.j: 通季は母藤原光子が正妻だったため嫡子とされたが、早世したために兄弟の中でも官位が最も低かった。
sen.e: Michisue was made heir because his mother FUJIWARA no Mitsuko was a lawful wife, but his official rank was the lowest among his brothers since he died young.
Michisue was made an heir because his mother FUJIWARA no Mitsuko was a lawful wife, but due to his early death he did not attain an official rank equal to that of his brothers.
Michisue was made an heir because his mother FUJIWARA no Mitsuko was a lawful wife, but due to his early death he did not attain an official rank equal to that of his brothers.

sen.j: 四代目の太政大臣西園寺公経（1171年 - 1244年）に至って、親幕派として承久の乱後権勢を誇り、摂関家から外戚の地位と関東申次の世襲職を奪った。
sen.e: The fourth generation, grand minister of state Kintsune SAIONJI (1171 to 1244), held the reins of power as a pro-shogunate group after Jokyu-no-ran War and seized the position of maternal relative and the hereditary job position of Kanto Moshitsugi from Sekkan Family.

The fourth generation, that of Grand Minister of State Kintsune SAIONJI (1171 to 1244), held the reins of power as a pro-shogunate group after the Jokyu-no-ran War, thereby seizing the position of maternal relative and the hereditary job position of Kanto Moshitsugi from the Sekkan Family.

The fourth generation, that of Grand Minister of State Kintsune SAIONJI (1171 to 1244), held the reins of power as a pro-shogunate group after the Jokyu-no-ran War, thereby seizing the position of maternal relative and the hereditary job position of Kanto Moshitsugi from the Sekkan Family.

sen.j: 公経は京洛北山に氏寺西園寺を建立して、家名の由来となった。
sen.e: Kintsune built Ujidera (temple built for praying clan's glory), Saionji, in Kyoraku (Kyoto) Kitayama, which became the origin of the family name.
Kintsune built the ujidera (a temple built for praying for clan glory), Saionji, in Kyoraku (Kyoto) Kitayama, thus originating the family name.
Kintsune built the ujidera (a temple built for praying for clan glory), Saionji, in Kyoraku (Kyoto) Kitayama, thus originating the family name.

sen.j: 庶流に洞院家（断絶）・今出川家（菊亭家）、羽林家の清水谷家・四辻家・橋本家・大宮家等あり。
sen.e: The branch family includes Toin Family (died out), Imadegawa Family (Kikutei Family), and Shimizudani Family, Yotsutuji Family, and Omiya Family of Urin Family.
The branch family included the Toin Family (which died out), Imadegawa Family (Kikutei Family), Shimizudani Family, Yotsutuji Family and Omiya Family (of the Urin Family).
The branch family included the Toin Family (which died out), Imadegawa Family (Kikutei Family), Shimizudani Family, Yotsutuji Family, Hashimoto Family and Omiya Family of the Urin Family.

sen.e: Karoku (hereditary stipend) in the Edo era: 597 koku, Crest: Hidari-mitsudomoe.

sen.e: Tokudaiji Family

sen.j: 藤原北家閑院流。
sen.e: Fujiwara Hokke-Kanin group.
The Fujiwara Hokke-Kanin group
The Fujiwara Hokke-Kanin group

sen.j: 公実三男左大臣徳大寺実能（1096年 - 1157年）を始祖とする。
sen.e: The originator is Kimizane's third son, minister of the right Saneyoshi TOKUDAIJI (1096 to 1157).
The originator is Kimizane's third son, Minister of the Right Saneyoshi TOKUDAIJI (1096 to 1157).
The originator was Kimizane's third son, Minister of the Left Saneyoshi TOKUDAIJI (1096 to 1157).

sen.j: 実能の嫡孫、左大臣徳大寺実定（1139年 - 1191年）は藤原俊成の妹が生んだ子で藤原定家の従兄にあたり、自らも優れた歌人である。
sen.e: Saneyoshi's grandchild who fell heir to the family, ministor of the left Sanesada TOKUDAIJI (1139 TO 1191) is FUJIWARA no Toshinari's younger sister's son and FUJIWARA no Sadaie's cousin, and is a excellent poet.

Saneyoshi's grandchild who fell heir to the family, Minister of the Left Sanesada TOKUDAIJI (1139 TO 1191), was FUJIWARA no Toshinari's younger sister's son and FUJIWARA no Sadaie's cousin, and was a gifted poet.

Saneyoshi's grandchild, who became heir to the family, Minister of the Left Sanesada TOKUDAIJI (1139 to 1191), was FUJIWARA no Toshinari's younger sister's son and FUJIWARA no Sadaie's cousin, and was a gifted poet.

sen.j: この家は鳥羽天皇・後白河天皇院政期の後宮をほぼ独占したが、鎌倉時代以後やや衰えた。
sen.e: This family almost dominated Kokyu the Palace in the cloister government period by Toba Emperor and Goshirakawa Emperor, but the power of the family was kind of withering away after the Kamakura era.

This family nearly dominated the kokyu of the palace during the period of cloister government by the emperors Toba and Goshirakawa, but the power of the family dwindled somewhat after the Kamakura era.

This family nearly dominated the kokyu of the palace during the period of cloister government by the emperors Toba and Goshirakawa, but the power of the family dwindled somewhat after the Kamakura era.

sen.j: 西園寺家と同族意識が強く、たとえば明治時代の西園寺公望は徳大寺家に生まれ西園寺家に入嗣。
sen.e: Tokudaiji Family had a strong sense of kindred with Saionji Family, and, for instance, Kinmochi SAIONJI in the Meiji era was born in Tokudaiji Family and was adopted by Saionji Family (Nyushi (join the family to be a heir)).

The Tokudaiji Family had a strong kindred connection to the Saionji Family; for example, in the Meiji period Kinmochi SAIONJI was born into the Tokudaiji Family and subsequently adopted by the Saionji Family (as an act of nyushi (joining the family to become an heir)).

The Tokudaiji Family had a strong kindred connection to the Saionji Family; for example, in the Meiji period Kinmochi SAIONJI was born into the Tokudaiji Family and subsequently adopted by the Saionji Family (as an act of nyushi (joining the family to become an heir)).

sen.j: 家業：笛、江戸時代の家禄：約410石、家紋：木瓜花菱浮線綾。
sen.e: Family business: flute, Karoku (hereditary stipend) in the Edo era: about 410 koku, Crest: Mokko-Hanabishi-Fusenryo crest (rhombic gourd flowers in a circle).

sen.j: 花山院家
sen.e: Kazanin Family
The Kazanin Family

sen.j: 藤原北家師実流（花山院流）。
sen.e: Fujiwara Hokke-Morozane group (Kazanin group).
The Fujiwara Hokke-Morozane group (Kazanin group)
The Fujiwara Hokke-Morozane group (Kazanin group)

sen.j: 摂政太政大臣藤原師実の次子右大臣花山院家忠（1062年 - 1136年）より始まる。
sen.e: The originator is minister of the right Ietada KAZANIN (1062 to 1136), who is the second child of regent, grand minister of state, FUJIWARA no Morozane.
The originator was Minister of the Right Ietada KAZANIN (1062 to 1136), who was the second child of the regent, Grand Minister of State FUJIWARA no Morozane.
The originator was Minister of the Right Ietada KAZANIN (1062 to 1136), who was the second child of the regent, Grand Minister of State FUJIWARA no Morozane.

sen.j: 家忠が花山天皇の御所だった東一条院（花山院）を伝領したためこの家名がある。
sen.e: The family name comes from the fact that Ietada inherited Higashi-Ichijoin (Kazanin) that was the imperial palace of Kazan Emperor.
The family name came from the fact that Ietada had inherited Higashi-Ichijoin (Kazanin), the Imperial Palace of Emperor Kazan.
The family name came from the fact that Ietada had inherited Higashi-Ichijoin (Kazanin), the Imperial Palace of Emperor Kazan.

sen.j: 三代花山院忠雅（1124年 - 1193年）は朝政に明るかった上に、平清盛と親戚関係にあったことから、太政大臣という異例の昇進を遂げた。
sen.e: Because the third generation, Tadamasa KAZANIN (1124 to 1193), was familiar with Emperor's politics in the Imperial and was a relative of TAIRA no Kiyomori, he was exceptionally promoted to grand minister of state.

Because the third generation, Tadamasa KAZANIN (1124 to 1193), was familiar with the Emperor's politics in the Imperial Palace and was a relative of TAIRA no Kiyomori, he was exceptionally promoted to be the grand minister of state.

Because the third generation, Tadamasa KAZANIN (1124 to 1193), was familiar with the Emperor's politics in the Imperial Palace and was a relative of TAIRA no Kiyomori, he was exceptionally promoted to be the grand minister of state.

sen.j: 諸流に羽林家の中山家・野宮家・今城家がある。
sen.e: The various school includes Nakayama Family, Nonomiya Family, Imaki Family of Urin Family.
The various schools included the Nakayama Family, Nonomiya Family and Imaki Family (of the Urin Family).
The various schools included the Nakayama Family, Nonomiya Family and Imaki Family of the Urin Family.

sen.j: 家業：笙と筆道、江戸時代の家禄：約750石、家紋：杜若菱。
sen.e: Family business: Sho flute and art of calligraphy, Karoku (hereditary stipend) in the Edo era: about 750 koku, Crest: Kakitsubata-hisi crest (rhombic Japanese iris).
Family business: sho flute and art of calligraphy; karoku (hereditary stipend) in the Edo period: about 750 koku; crest: the Kakitsubata-hisi (rhombic Japanese iris).
Family business: sho flute and art of calligraphy; karoku (hereditary stipend) in the Edo period: about 750 koku; crest: the Kakitsubata-hisi (rhombic Japanese iris).

sen.j: 大炊御門家
sen.e: Oinomikado Family
The Oinomikado Family
The Oinomikado Family

sen.j: 藤原北家師実流（花山院流）。
sen.e: Fujiwara Hokke-Morozane group (Kazanin group).
The Fujiwara Hokke-Morozane group (Kazanin group)
The Fujiwara Hokke-Morozane group (Kazanin group)

sen.j: 花山院家と同じく摂政師実の子大炊御門経実（1068年 - 1131年）が初代。
sen.e: The originator is Tsunezane OINOMIKADO (1068 to 1131), who is also a child of FUJIWARA no Morozane, like Kazanin Family.
The originator is Tsunezane OINOMIKADO (1068 to 1131), who was also a child of FUJIWARA no Morozane, like the Kazanin Family.
The originator is Tsunezane OINOMIKADO (1068 to 1131), who was also a child of FUJIWARA no Morozane, like the Kazanin Family.

sen.j: 大炊御門北、万里小路東に邸宅があった。
sen.e: The house was located in the north of Oinomikado and the east of Made-no-Koji street.
The house was located north of Oinomikado and east of Made-no-Koji street.
The house was located north of Oinomikado and east of Made-no-Koji street.

sen.j: 経実は権大納言どまりであったが、その子大炊御門経宗（1119年 - 1189年）は二条天皇の外舅として勢威をふるい、左大臣に昇って清華家の家格を確保した（経宗は閑院流公実の女公子を母とする）。
sen.e: Tsunezane was only promoted up to supernumerary chief councillor of state, but his son Tsunemune OINOMIKADO (1119 to 1189) held the veins of power as maternal father of Nijo Emperor and was promoted to minister of the left to ensure the Kakaku (family status) of Seiga Family (Tsunemune's mother is Kimiko, a daughter of Kinzane KANINRYU).

Tsunezane was promoted only up to supernumerary chief councilor of state, but his son Tsunemune OINOMIKADO (1119 to 1189) held the reins of power as the maternal father of Emperor Nijo and was promoted to minister of the left so as to ensure the kakaku (family status) of the Seiga Family (Tsunemune's mother was Kimiko, a daughter of Kinzane KANINRYU).

Tsunezane was promoted only up to supernumerary chief councilor of state, but his son Tsunemune OINOMIKADO (1119 to 1189) held the reins of power as the maternal father of Emperor Nijo and was promoted to minister of the left so as to ensure the kakaku (family status) of the Seiga Family (Tsunemune's mother was Kimiko, a daughter of Kinzane KANINRYU).

sen.j: 家業：筆道・和歌・和琴・笛・装束、江戸時代の家禄：約400石、家紋：菱に片喰草。
sen.e: Family business: calligraphy, Waka/Yamatouta, thirteen-stringed koto, Japanese, Shozoku (costume); Karoku (hereditary stipend) in the Edo era: about 400 koku; Crest: Hishi ni Katabamiso crest (diamond and cuckooflower).

Family business: calligraphy, Waka/Yamatouta, thirteen-string koto, Japanese, shozoku (costume); karoku (hereditary stipend) in the Edo period: about 400 koku; crest: the Hishi ni Katabamiso (diamond and cuckooflower)

Family business: calligraphy, waka (yamatouta), thirteen-string koto, Japanese harp, flute, shozoku (costume); karoku (hereditary stipend) in the Edo period: about 400 koku; crest: the Hishi ni Katabamiso (diamond and cuckooflower)

sen.j: 藤原北家閑院流、西園寺家の庶流。
sen.e: Fujiwara Hokke-Kanin group, branch family of Saionji Family.
The Fujiwara Hokke-Kanin group, a branch of the Saionji Family
The Fujiwara Hokke-Kanin group, a branch of the Saionji Family

sen.j: 鎌倉期の太政大臣西園寺実兼の子左大臣今出川兼季が分家し、今出川殿を居所としたため、菊亭・今出川を名乗る。
sen.e: Minister of the left Kanesue IMADEGAWA, who was a son of Sanekane SAIONJI, gand minister of state in the Kamakura period, started a branch family of Saionji Family, and resided in Imadegawa-dono palace, and therefore they called themselves Kikutei, Imadegawa.

Minister of the Left Kanesue IMADEGAWA, who was a son of Sanekane SAIONJI, a grand minister of state during the Kamakura period, started a branch of the Saionji Family and resided in Imadegawa-dono palace; accordingly, they called themselves Kikutei (Imadegawa).

Minister of the Left Kanesue IMADEGAWA, who was a son of Sanekane SAIONJI, a grand minister of state during the Kamakura period, started a branch of the Saionji Family and resided in Imadegawa-dono palace; accordingly, they called themselves Kikutei (Imadegawa).

sen.j: 維新後は今出川を改め、別称の菊亭を名字とした。
sen.e: After the Restoration, the family name, Imadegawa, was changed to another name, Kikutei.
After the Restoration the family name, Imadegawa, was changed to another name: Kikutei.
After the Restoration the family name, Imadegawa, was changed to another name: Kikutei.

sen.j: 家業：琵琶。

sen.j: 摂政一条昭良の次男権大納言醍醐冬基（1648年 - 1697年）が初代。
sen.e: The first generation is chief councillor of state Fuyumoto DAIGO (1648 to 1697), the second son of regent Akiyoshi ICHIJO.
The first generation was Chief Councilor of State Fuyumoto DAIGO (1648 to 1697), the second son of the regent, Akiyoshi ICHIJO.

sen.j: 正親町天皇の皇孫八条宮智仁親王の男子、広幡忠幸（1623年 - 1669年）が臣籍降下して創立。
sen.e: Tadayuki HIROHATA (1623 to 1669), a son of Hachijo no Miya Toshihito Prince who was imperial descendant of Ogimachi Emperor, did Shinseki Koka (demotion by Meiji Constitution that Imperial family lose their rank to be normal people) started the family.

Tadayuki HIROHATA (1623 to 1669), a son of Hachijo no Miya (Prince Toshihito), who was an imperial descendant of Emperor Ogimachi, underwent shinseki koka (demotion by Meiji Constitution whereby the Imperial Family lost its rank to become common people), started the family.

Tadayuki HIROHATA (1623 to 1669), a son of Hachijo no Miya (Prince Toshihito), who was an imperial descendant of Emperor Ogimachi, underwent shinseki koka (demotion by Meiji Constitution whereby the Imperial Family lost its rank to become common people), started the family.

sen.j: 忠幸は最初、尾張藩に赴き武家となったが、のち帰洛して大納言に進んだ。
sen.e: At first, Tadayuki went to domain of Owari to become a samurai family, but then became chief councillor of state by backing to Kyoto.
Initially, Tadayuki went to he domain of Owari to become a samurai family, but then became chief councilor of state by backing Kyoto.
Initially, Tadayuki went to ｔhe domain of Owari to become a samurai family, but upon his return to Kyoto he became Dainagon (chief councilor of state).
sen.cmt: he→the帰洛してを修正"the chief councilor of state" -> "Dainagon (chief councilor of state)" に変更しました。

sen.j: 禄高：約500石、家紋：十六葉裏菊。
